text: (soft music)
All right.
We've heard some very nice talks
about the use of chemistry to address challenges
in biomedical applications,
and the study of chemistry in cosmological context.
As we look towards the future,
we realize that modeling and computation
plays an integral role in each of those areas.
And as those arenas are increasingly sophisticated
and the questions are more and more advanced,
the computational requirements fail quickly.
And so we're looking at building hardware of the future
to host these future discoveries in a variety
of different areas and to do that,
you're going to need organic materials.
And so that's what I'll discuss today.
Designing materials to enable that future.
Before I go into a brief bio or introduction of myself,
I'd first like to thank the organizers
for hosting this symposium
and all their hard work for putting this together.
I'd also like to thank Bob Allen.
He's the senior manager of materials here
at IBM Almaden research center.
And he's been a fantastic mentor
that's really opened up a lot of opportunities for myself
and younger scientists.
So thank you very much, Bob.
In 2013, I completed my PhD in macromolecular science
and engineering from Case Western Reserve university
as a member of Stuart Rowan's crew.
And this was supported
by a NASA graduate student fellowship.
And I was co-advised by Michael Meador,
the director of materials at NASA plant at the time.
And during my graduate work,
I exploited super molecular interactions
to complete the synthesis of a non-natural product,
the ploy-n catenate.
And this unique polymer
was based on mechanical (indistinct).
Essentially, you can think of this like molecular chain.
It was during my studies as a undergraduate
and in graduate research
that I really saw the impact of IBM research.
I was familiar with some of the most remarkable work
that they published in a high profile research
that really pushed the limits of nanotechnology
in projects such as the millipede,
where AFM cantilevers were used to manipulate
a polymer surface to create a dense memory array
for manipulating individual atoms to spell out IBM
or create a quantum corral.
So it was really a dream to be a part of IBM research.
And as I was completing my graduate work,
I was fortunate enough to have the opportunity
to join L Nelson's group
who was a manager of a self assembly group at the time.
And I worked under him as an advisory engineer
to manage and leverage (indistinct)
hardware to advanced research in a number
of different project areas.
And it was at,
after he left to join the faculty
at the University of Washington,
I joined Dan Sanders group and essentially reinvented myself
in this research interest to connect materials
to solve some of the ongoing challenges in IBM hardware.
And this is what led me to where I am today
as this manager of novel electronic materials,
devices, and process technology.
So let's first talk a bit about nanofabrication.
This is really a critical foundation
used to make a variety of different devices.
And what I feature here is the IBM power nine processor.
So this is a processor that contains
over 8 billion transistors.
And recently, IBM's announced the power 10 processor
with now 18 billion transistors in the same unit area.
The backbone of device fabrication
uses patternable materials to create these transistors
at the very small length scales.
And we didn't just start by printing out
the single nanometer feature sizes,
but we've come a long way since the introduction
of microelectronics.
And these have really relied on polymeric materials
to really push the resolution,
to push the ability to pattern and fabricate devices
to where we are today.
And so, as I think of it,
materials are really the enabling component
or one of many enabling components
that get us to these amazing computational power
that we have at our fingertips today in our cell phones,
and that we're using today to host events like this.
It is, however, becoming increasingly clear
that there is an additional future
that we have to think about.
After we get past seven nanometers,
there's discussions of a five
and three nanometer technology note.
After you get to those single nanometer feature sizes,
the future of computing is going to look very different.
So this may involve our traditional bits
as we're familiar with, transistors.
There may be other architectures that provide access
to different types
and different computational power densities,
such as this IBM nanosheet transistor.
But we've reached a point where we can look to the future
of the landscape of technology and the future of computing,
and we see that this new foundation is going to incorporate
not just those traditional bits,
but also integrate things like artificial neurons.
And this is a picture of the summit supercomputer
built by IBM.
And essentially, we think of this as a bits plus neurons
as a system.
So this is a special type of supercomputer
that can take advantage of not only CPUs and processors,
but GPUs to make a system that's capable of learning,
inferencing, and steering.
And one of the most advanced to date in this.
We also see the emergence of other types
of computational architectures,
like quantum computing that takes advantage
of superconducting circuits that behave
like artificial atoms.
So with these, you can manipulate them
and take advantage of these quantum mechanical properties,
like super position and entanglement
to address increasingly complex problems
like modeling chemical systems.
And these are poised to solve problems that we may consider
intractable with traditional computers today.
So like the advancement of,
like the advancement of the technology nodes
that were enabled with these
chemically amplified polymer resist,
so too will this landscape of a future of computing
draw from materials to enable, optimize,
and improve these types of systems.
So while we're working in each of those different areas
of AI, quantum, and your traditional bits,
I'll highlight one area that I can discuss in more detail,
and that is addressing some of the existing problems
that we have with making devices, but wiring to them.
So on the left-hand side,
this is an image of a typical wiring to device.
So you might be able to print a seven nanometer feature,
but bringing the outside world to that
and connecting to that can be very difficult.
And it relies on multiple levels of patterning
and then alignment.
So if you place a wire or via onto your device,
you need to place that in a very well controlled
on top of your metal level here labeled M1V0.
If you're off, if your alignment's off even slightly,
you can introduce variability into the device performance.
If you're off even at slightly more,
you can short devices, which impacts yield.
And so if we could find a way of,
instead of depositing a material in a selective manner
instead of having to do this type of alignment,
that would provide a huge advantage in terms
of being able to connect our devices to the outside world.
And so part of our work was looking at
a selective deposition or a selective alignment
where you could take advantage of a surface composed
of dissimilar materials and exploit the chemistry
of those surfaces to block deposition
on one and not another.
And thereby, you could have a correct placement
without having to do this patterning stuff.
And while this field of self alignment is not new,
the use of custom and synthesized materials
are growing on in terms of the interests.
So one of the things we did is we took a material
that's very effective at depositing and blocking thin films
and the selective deposition of those,
it's this green molecule
you see pictured to the upper right.
Now after so many,
such a thickness of film that's deposited,
you'll start to see your loss of selectivity.
And we started wondering if we could address
this loss of selectivity and understand
the relationship between selectivity and the material
by developing our own types of inhibitors.
And so we looked at a variety
of different types of interacting,
either through Pi Pi stacking and hydrogen bonding,
or a variety of other types of interacting components
to realize a more selective process
or a highly selective one
that you see in the lower right hand corner
using the same conditions.
Now, we also see people start to,
and are using not just planar surfaces
and planar structures,
but are resorting to three-dimensional types
of electronic devices.
And if you want to use a small molecule
like this pictured here,
this hydroxamic acid is very effective at inhibiting
the growth of zinc oxide on a planar film
up to 500 ALD cycles as it's labeled here.
But after that, you start losing selectivity.
However, if you just take that planar surface
and add topography to it,
there is a complete loss of selectivity.
That is very difficult for these small molecules
to cover corners and edges.
And so, we've developed a way of selectively polymerizing
from a metal surface,
a norbornene type of polymer is very effective
at inhibiting those very rough surfaces
or surfaces with feature sizes that are out of plane.
And this allowed us to deposit selectively in the trench
or bare silicon surface of this structure
that you see in the lower right-hand corner.
And we demonstrate this at a large scale
showing that we could very well control
this polymerization and guide deposition
to a Sierpinski like a fractal pattern.
So looking beyond what we can do
additionally with the materials aspect
of these selected depositions,
we looked at if there's an additional level of control
that you may be able to exert with that
through patterning types of steps.
And this is what we described as additive lithography
or an additive process
where you can introduce a material,
as opposed to a subtractive method of lithography
or a traditional approach to that.
There may be advantages in this additive approach,
such that you do not have to subject a material
to a high energy etch process that may
(indistinct) sidewalls or lead to damage to your material.
This also gives you the control
that you would not otherwise have in a selective deposition
that is a simple reflection of the underlying pre pattern.
And so this tailorable area selective deposition
using this exposure technique is one that gives
additional benefit to traditional methods of doing this.
And so, we found that by tailoring our packing density
of these types of inhibitors,
we could control this process very well.
And with an underlying creep pattern
that you see in this schematic pictured,
we can selectively irradiate areas of these inhibitors
and block deposition to spell out IBM, for instance.
We can see a dose dependence or a dependence
on how highly cross-linked that film is
and how well that translates to blocking
any sort of film growth from those areas,
as well as arbitrary future generation.
And so this gives us more control than one might have
from just an area selective method of providing its own.
And so with that, I'll conclude.
This is a lot of work that's been contributed to
a lot of great and fantastic literatures.
And so, we've done a lot of this together
with our colleagues at IBM semiconductor research,
and some of the characterization of that last portion
of being able to pattern our monolayer materials
and generate different types of features
are characterized and exposed at Lawrence Berkeley
with our collaborators at CXRO.
With that, I'll take any questions.
Thank you so much, Rudy, for another fascinating talk.
It's been great to see so many different kinds of chemistry
throughout the day.
Because we are so close to time
and there's another session after ours,
I think we're gonna skip the Q and A,
but thank you so much for joining us today
and sticking around to hear all this great science.
Goodbye.
